content:
ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute Class

Definition

Represents a security attribute used to declaratively assign access checks based on the logic provided by the ClaimsAuthorizationManager instance in the current application context. This class cannot be inherited.

In this Article

[System.AttributeUsage(System.AttributeTargets.Class | System.AttributeTargets.Method | System.AttributeTargets.Property, AllowMultiple=true)]
public sealed class ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute : System.Security.Permissions.CodeAccessSecurityAttribute
Inheritance
Object
Attribute
SecurityAttribute
System.Security.Permissions.CodeAccessSecurityAttribute
ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute

Examples

The following example shows how to protect a method by decorating it with the ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute attribute. The attribute will evaluate whether access should be granted to the current principal by leveraging the logic provided by the ClaimsAuthorizationManager instance in the application context. If the current principal is not authorized for the specified action on the specified resource, a SecurityException is thrown; otherwise, execution proceeds. 


//
// Declarative access check using the permission class. The caller must satisfy both demands.
//
[ClaimsPrincipalPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, Resource = "resource", Operation = "action")]
[ClaimsPrincipalPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, Resource = "resource1", Operation = "action1")]
static void ProtectedMethod()
{
}

The following XML shows the minimum configuration required to use a custom claims authorization manager with the ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute class. You must, at a minimum, declare both the system.identityModel and the system.identityModel.services sections in the <configSection> element and then specify your authorization manager in a <claimsAuthorizationManager> element under the default identity configuration. This will ensure that your authorization manager is referenced from the default federation configuration. Alternatively, you can specify the name of the identity configuration under which your authorization manager is specified in the identityConfigurationName attribute of the <federationConfiguration> element. 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>  
<configuration>  
  <configSections>  
    <!-- WIF configuration sections -->  
    <section name="system.identityModel" type="System.IdentityModel.Configuration.SystemIdentityModelSection, System.IdentityModel, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=B77A5C561934E089"/>  
    <section name="system.identityModel.services" type="System.IdentityModel.Services.Configuration.SystemIdentityModelServicesSection, System.IdentityModel.Services, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=B77A5C561934E089"/>  
  </configSections>  

  <startup>  
    <supportedRuntime version="v4.0" sku=".NETFramework,Version=v4.5" />  
  </startup>  

  <system.identityModel>  
    <identityConfiguration>  
      <claimsAuthorizationManager type ="MyClaimsAuthorizationManager.MyClaimsAuthorizationManager, MyClaimsAuthorizationManager"/>  
    </identityConfiguration>  
  </system.identityModel>  

</configuration>

Remarks

The ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute is used to declaratively request an access check using the configured ClaimsAuthorizationManager.

You must specify one of the SecurityAction values, a Resource and an Operation in your ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute declaration. The Resource and Operation properties specify the resource and action for which the current principal (CurrentPrincipal) must be authorized for execution to proceed. If the current principal is not authorized to perform the specified action (operation) on the specified resource, a SecurityException is thrown.

Important

The ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute class uses the claims authorization manager configured by the IdentityConfiguration that is set under the FederationConfiguration property. This is true in all cases, even in scenarios where WS-Federation is not used; for example, active (WCF) Web applications and Console applications. You can specify the claims authorization manager either in configuration or programmatically. To specify the claims authorization manager in a configuration file, set the <claimsAuthorizationManager> element under an <identityConfiguration> element and ensure that this identity configuration is referenced by the <federationConfiguration> element that is loaded by the runtime (for example, by setting the identityConfigurationName attribute). To set the claims authorization manager programmatically, provide a handler for the System.IdentityModel.Services.FederatedAuthentication.FederationConfigurationCreated event.

Constructors

ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute(SecurityAction)

Initializes a new instance of the ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute class.

public ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute (System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction action);
action
SecurityAction

One of the values that specifies the security actions that can be performed when using declarative security.

Remarks

You must also specify the Operation and Resource properties in your ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute declaration or an exception will be thrown when the CreatePermission method is invoked to create the permission.

Properties

Operation

Gets or sets the operation for which the current principal should be authorized on the specified resource.

public string Operation { get; set; }
Value
String

The action for which the current principal should be authorized.

Remarks

The operation is the action for which the current principal should be authorized on the specified resource. You must set the Operation property in your ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute declaration or an exception will be thrown when the CreatePermission method is called to create the permission.

Resource

Gets or sets the resource on which the principal should be authorized to perform the specified action (operation).

public string Resource { get; set; }
Value
String

The resource on which the current principal should be authorized.

Remarks

The resource on which the current principal should be authorized to perform the specified action. You must set the Resource property in your ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute declaration or an exception will be thrown when the CreatePermission method is called to create the permission.

Methods

CreatePermission()

Creates new instance of the ClaimsPrincipalPermission class that is based on the current instance.

public override System.Security.IPermission CreatePermission ();
Returns
IPermission

A ClaimsPrincipalPermission with the operation and resource associated with this instance.

Remarks

The ClaimsPrincipalPermission object is created by using the value of the Operation property and the Resource property. You must specify the Operation and Resource properties in your ClaimsPrincipalPermissionAttribute declaration or an exception will be thrown when the CreatePermission method is invoked to create the permission.
